item.title: Daniela add a quote by Audrey Hepburn
item.description:
"I have to be alone very often. I'd be quite happy if I spent from Saturday night until Monday morning alone in my apartment. That's how I refuel."
(<i>Audrey Hepburn: Many-Sided Charmer</i>, LIFE Magazine, December 7, 1953)" -- Audrey Hepburn

item.title: Daniela add a quote by Rainer Maria Rilke
item.description: "I want to be with those who know secret things or else alone." -- Rainer Maria Rilke

item.title: Daniela add a quote by Albert Camus
item.description:
"In order to understand the world, one has to turn away from it on occasion."
[<i>The Minotaur</i>]" -- Albert Camus

item.title: Daniela add a quote by Kazuo Ishiguro
item.description: "Sometimes I get so immersed in my own company, if I unexpectedly run into someone I know, it's a bit of a shock and takes me a while to adjust." -- Kazuo Ishiguro

item.title: Daniela add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "How much better is silence; the coffee cup, the table. How much better to sit by myself like the solitary sea-bird that opens its wings on the stake. Let me sit here for ever with bare things, this coffee cup, this knife, this fork, things in themselves, myself being myself." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Daniela add a quote by Saul Bellow
item.description: "I should have written you a letter, it was too late to make the deaths of my brothers an excuse. Since they died, I wrote a book; why not a letter? A mysterious but truthful answer is that while I can gear myself up to do a novel, letters, real-life communications, are too much for me. I used to rattle them off easily enough; why is the challenge of writing to friends and acquaintances too much for me now? Because I have become such a solitary, and not in the Aristotelian sense: not a beast, not a god. Rather, a loner troubled by longings, incapable of finding a suitable language and despairing at the impossibility of composing messages in a playable key--as if I no longer understood the codes used by the estimable people who wanted to hear from me and would have so much to reply if only the impediments were taken away." -- Saul Bellow
